After a challenging first season at the helm, which saw United finish 14th in the Premier League and lose the Europa League final to Tottenham Hotspur, the Portuguese head coach is keen to avoid another disappointing campaign.

Amorim, who took over from Erik ten Hag after moving from Sporting Lisbon, is said to have made a personal appeal to United's top brass to recruit Valentim, according to Portuguese publication Record [via the Mirror]. The 49-year-old previously worked with Amorim at their former club Braga, and the United boss is reportedly eager for a reunion at Old Trafford.
Read more here
Manchester United have been backed to complete two major transfers involving Aston Villa players this summer.

The Reds are in desperate need of a new striker this summer after an abysmal goalscoring record in 2024/25. United's 44 goals in the Premier League was their lowest in a generation, with striker Rasmus Hojlund among several attackers who failed to deliver.

Viktor Gyokeres, Victor Osimhen and Hugo Ekitike have been among the many strikers linked with a move to M16 as Ruben Amorim desperately seeks a solution to his goalscoring crisis. Any one of those players would be an upgrade on United's current options up-front.
Read the full piece here

Left-back Alvaro Fernandez has been heavily linked with a move to Real Madrid. He moved to Benfica last summer for £5million and United are said to have inserted a 20 per cent sell-on clause in the deal.
He is said to have a release clause of £42million and if Real Madrid trigger that then it means United should be entitled to a windfall of around £7.4million.
Read the full piece here
Manchester United are looking to wrap up the signing of Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo before the start of their pre-season.

The Reds return to training in the week commencing July 7 with one signing already secured. United signed Wolves forward Matheus Cunha earlier this month after activating the £62.5 million release clause in his contract. The Brazilian joined on a five-year contract, with the option of another year.
Read more here
Fenerbahce are reportedly not in talks to sign Jadon Sancho.
Journalist Fabrizio Romano claims that their main focus is former Aston Villa striker Jhon Duran.

Sancho, 25, spent last season on loan at Premier League rivals Chelsea but - despite their £25million obligation to make that move permanent - the Blues opted to pay a £5million penalty fee to send him back to M16.
An update has been provided on the future of Manchester United-linked Emiliano Martinez.

The 2022 World Cup-winning goalkeeper faces an uncertain future at Aston Villa. Martinez was seen in tears after the Villans' final home game of the Premier League in 2024/25 as he considers starting a new chapter in his career.

Martinez signed a new contract 10 months ago, committing his long-term future to the club. However, it now appears uncertain. After failing to secure a financially lucrative place in next season's Champions League, Villa could be tempted to cash in on the 32-year-old, who turns 33 later this year.
Read more here
Manchester United have reportedly been told Viktor Gyokeres' preferences amid transfer links with the Reds.

Reports from our colleagues at The Mirror claimed on Thursday that Gyokeres has made a U-turn on United after previous claims that he preferred a move to Arsenal. The Sweden international knows Reds boss Ruben Amorim well from their time in Portugal together, while many at Old Trafford will be hoping this could help them convince him to join the M16 club.
Read more here
Hello and welcome to our live blog on the latest Manchester United transfer news, views and opinions.
News emerged on Friday night that the Reds have had an improved bid for Bryan Mbeumo rejected by Brentford.
It is claimed that the Reds have bid £55million plus £7.5m in add-ons for the 25-year-old.
We'll be providing all the latest on this story and more throughout the day so stick with us.
Manchester United are fast approaching a transfer deadline that could result in them getting more deals over the line.

Matheus Cunha remains the only new signing to Ruben Amorim's squad at United so far this summer. The transfer window has been open since June 16, and will remain so until September 1 which gives United plenty of time to complete their transfer business ahead of the 2025/26 Premier League campaign.

June 30 will mark the deadline for the financial year for Premier League clubs, including United, when it comes to the Profit & Sustainability Rules (PSR). As a result, from July 1, United and other clubs will see their financial business reset and allow them to go into the market for more new signings.
Click here to read the players United may be able to sanction moves for without having financial worries
The Cameroon international has again made his preference to play at Old Trafford clear if he departs the Bees but United are still below their £70million valuation.
The value of their second offer is the full fee paid to Wolves to sign Matheus Cunha with it appearing as though Brentford want £70million or perhaps more favourable payment terms.
Jadon Sancho has transfer interest from three clubs but there are several factors currently preventing a Manchester United exit
According to transfer guru Fabrizio Romano, all of Napoli, Juventus and Fenerbahce are willing to pay his £25million asking price but only the latter can afford his wage demands.
However, Sancho is not interested in a move to Turkiye where he would be coached by former United boss Jose Mourinho.
Bryan Mbeumo has insisted he will only join Manchester United if he leaves Brentford this summer, according to David Ornstein of the Athletic.
Tottenham have recently been linked to signing Mbeumo after Thomas Frank was confirmed as their new head coach but he will seemingly not be following him to north London.
United's two bids for the Cameroon international have thus far fallen short of the Bees' £70million valuation.
Liverpool have confirmed the signing of Freddie as their third-choice goalkeeper.
Manchester United had been linked to signing the 28-year-old on a free transfer following the expiration of his Preston North End contract.
Instead, United opted to agree a new contract with Tom Heaton in order to help ease any major worries over association trained players being in their squad.
Manchester United are interested in Borussia Dortmund star Felix Nmecha, it has been claimed in Germany.

Ruben Amorim is looking to bolster his midfield this summer with Christian Falk, via Caught Offside, naming Nmecha as a target. However, his report states Dortmund are 'fighting' to keep him at the club. The former Manchester City youth prospect is expected to cost in the region of £40million.
Elsewhere, Matheus Cunha's move from Wolves has already been confirmed with Bryan Mbeumo joining from Brentford also edging closer.
Manchester United's long-term interest in Jarrad Branthwaite looks set to end with the defender agreeing a new contract at Everton.
It is now being widely-reported that the 23-year-old will pen fresh terms at Goodison Park with five years agreed as the extension.

Multiple bids from Old Trafford back in the summer of 2023 were rebuffed by the Toffees but links continued to be present. Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro all joining saw those finally diminish and they are now seemingly all but gone.
Manchester United are looking for midfield reinforcements with a previous target seemingly again an option.
According to Calcio Mercato,while making it clear they will submit an offer for goalkeeper Marco Carnesecchi, a request was made to understand more about Ederson's future in Italy.

United are one of several Premier League clubs to be linked with the Brazil international. The 25-year-old has two years remaining on his contract with Atalanta said to be demanding a minimum of £51.3million (€60m) to sell.

Manchester United have declined Inter Milan's offer to send Mehdi Taremi to Old Trafford as part of a player-plus-cash deal for Rasmus Hojlund to go in the opposite direction, according to United In Focus.
Inter are keen on a summer deal for Hojlund and have been in talks with United over agreeing a possible move.
However, United want £40million for the Dane and Inter want a loan deal with an option to make the deal permanent.
After United rejected that approach, Inter decided to offer Taremi to Ruben Amorim's side and got a negative response.
Brentford have confirmed that Keith Andrews has been appointed as their new head coach, as the wait goes on for Bryan Mbeumo's move to Manchester United.

"Keith is a very good fit," said director of football Phil Giles. "He gets on with everyone, he's very open and he's a learner. Keith is clear in what he wants, he's detailed, and the players and staff like and respect him.

"He understands the players in the building and the way we've played and trained under Thomas Frank. Keith will bring his own evolution but isn’t starting from scratch, so hopefully we can make some quick progress."
Manchester United have made an 'offer' for Barcelona defender Ronald Araujo, according to reports in Spain.
The 26-year-old struggled for form and fitness in 2024/25 and was limited to just 25 appearances for Barcelona.
It has been suggested that the Uruguayan could be sacrificied this summer as Barcelona look to raise funds for Nico Williams.
As well as receiving an 'offer' from United for Araujo, Juventus and Bayern Munich have lodged a proposal each to sign the centre-back.
It is noted that Serie A giants Juventus were initially the only club in the race to sign Araujo, but he also has ‘offers’ from Man Utd and Bayern Munich.
Juve are the 'most advanced' club right now, but no one has yet done enough to tempt Barcelona to 'open the door' to his exit, with the minimum price set at around £34million.
Viktor Gyokeres has put Manchester United into pole position for his signature after making a U-turn on a move to Arsenal, according to the Mirror.
The Sporting CP forward scored 54 goals and added 13 assists in 52 matches last season and turned down a move to Juventus and Saudi Arabia last month.
With the Gunners expected to target Benjamin Sesko, Gyokeres is now prepared to reunite with former Sporting head coach Ruben Amorim, and his representatives have made contact.
Real Betis sporting director Manu Fajardo has delivered an update on the club's pursuit of another move for Manchester United forward Antony, following his successful loan spell last season.
Fajardo said, via Estadio Deportivo: "We all have to be aware that this is a very complex operation. Given the player’s level and his recent career at Real Betis, it’s not an easy transaction.

"But, as long as Antony hasn’t committed to a third party, we, with the utmost humility, will play our cards to be able to opt for Antony. I insist, despite this being a complex operation, we will try to carry it out in different ways without compromising the club.

"In the end, the most important thing is also the sustainability of the club. We will try to be creative, as we have been in the past, so that Antony can be here. Today, the market is open, as I said before, it’s very dynamic, and we are part of that game."
Manchester United are 'ready to submit an offer of £34.1million' for Atalanta goalkeeper Marco Carnesecchi and have 'asked for information' on one of his teammates, according to Calcio Mercato.
Carnesecchi impressed for Atalanta last season, keeping 18 clean sheets in all competitions, and could be available for transfer after the departure of Gian Piero Gasperini as head coach.
It's added that while United are prepared to make a £34.1m bid for Carnsecchi, Atalanta want between £38.4m and £42.6m to sanction the 24-year-old's exit in the summer transfer window.
As well as Carnesecchi, it appears that United remain keen on a deal for long-term target Ederson. The Reds have asked for more information on the Brazilian's situation at Old Trafford.
It is easy to understand why Manchester United were attracted to Liam Delap ahead of the start of this summer's transfer window.
The England Under-21 international was available via a £30million release clause this summer after his first season at Ipswich Town ended in relegation to the Championship.

After joining the Tractor Boys from Manchester City last summer, a £30m release clause was inserted into his contract that would become active if the Suffolk club were to fail to preserve its Premier League status.
Read more here
Former Manchester United defender Rio Ferdinand has outlined what he believes Bryan Mbeumo will bring to Old Trafford ahead of his expected arrival from Brentford.
Read more here
Manchester United return to pre-season training next month ahead of the new campaign.

Matheus Cunha will be the headline act as the Reds ramp up preparations for the 2025-26 season. Ruben Amorim's side will hope to improve on their dismal domestic showing last term and travel to America for a summer tour as well as playing in Sweden and at Old Trafford.
Read the full story here

headline: Ruud van Nistelrooy receives clear Man United response after Leicester City decision
body: Ruud van Nistelrooy has received a Manchester United response after leaving Leicester City.

The former Reds striker, assistant manager and interim manager joined Leicester after a brief period in charge of United last year following Erik ten Hag's sacking in October. The Reds went unbeaten during his four-game spell in charge with two wins over the Foxes, a victory over PAOK and a draw against Chelsea.

But the keys to Old Trafford on a permanent basis were handed to Ruben Amorim, and Van Nistelrooy left M16 shortly after the former Sporting boss was appointed in November. The Dutchman was not out of work for long, though, with Premier League relegation battlers Leicester turning to the ex-PSV Eindhoven boss.

It was hoped that Van Nistelrooy's arrival at the King Power Stadium would lead to a top-flight survival after his reasonably impressive spell at United for a brief period. But results continued to nosedive, and the Foxes were relegated to the Championship, finishing the 2024/25 season in 18th place, 13 points from safety.
Van Nistelrooy has subsequently left Leicester with his departure confirmed on Friday. And the 48-year-old has now sent a heartfelt message on his Instagram account to the East Midlands club.

"I would like to personally thank the @lcfc players, coaches, academy and all the staff I have worked with for their professionalism and dedication during my time at the club and to thank the fans for their support, and take this opportunity to wish the club well for the future," he said.
Van Nistelrooy's post has received several likes from those connected to United, including former Reds teammate Rio Ferdinand and current centre-back Lisandro Martinez.

Announcing his departure in a club statement, Leicester said: "Leicester City Football Club and Ruud van Nistelrooy have mutually agreed that Ruud’s contract with the Club as First Team Manager will terminate with immediate effect.

"Ruud has overseen a challenging period for the Club. From his appointment in November 2024, he approached the role with professionalism, integrity and a clear commitment to our aims, including through the integration of several promising players from the Club’s Academy into our First Team environment.
"Ruud moves on with the respect and thanks of everyone at the Football Club for his dedication and hard work, and with our very best wishes for the future."

headline: £85m star with 'no limits' can solve Man United transfer issue - and Thierry Henry loves him
body: Manchester United are expected to be busy in the transfer market this summer.
The Reds moved quickly to secure the £62.5million signing of Matheus Cunha and are making progress in their bid to sign Bryan Mbeumo in a move in excess of £60million.
Those two players scored 37 goals between them last season and could occupy the two attacking midfield slots in Ruben Amorim's 3-4-2-1 formation.
United's lack of goals last season was a real issue and signing a new forward is a priority this summer.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.
However, Amorim is keen to sign a new midfielder, too, to bring competition for the likes of Bruno Fernandes, Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo.
Links to who that midfielder may be have been few and far between but talk of a move for teenage midfielder Warren Zaire-Emery has tentatively emerged this week.

The 19-year-old is already a France international and a serial trophy-winner with PSG, and first came to the attention of English football fans with an excellent performance against Newcastle United in the Champions League back in 2023 when he was just 17.
Despite Les Parisiens losing the game at St James' Park, Zaire-Emery stood out as one of the best players on the pitch.

He caught the eye of former Arsenal and Barcelona forward Thierry Henry that evening, while he was working as a pundit for CBS Sports, and he later made him the captain of France Under-21s while he was manager.
"The way Warren Zaire-Emery is playing, it is normal to run the show at just 17 years old," Henry said.
"He was the only one that held his ground at St James’ Park. He’s been magnificent… the sky is the limit. I have never seen a player that young being so mature.

"Usually, you have youngsters that play as forwards that make the difference. But when you play in midfield for a team like PSG, you need to readjust. It is rare to see such a young player in that position.
"I gave him the armband (as France U21s boss) because I wanted to see the next thing.
"I know that physically he is strong, he can run, he can see a pass, he can stop a counter. I want to know if he can also stop a player by talking.
"I gave him the armband to know if he could direct the team and talk. That was my way of seeing if he could do that, and trust me, he can. This guy has no limits."
Still a teenager, Zaire-Emery's ceiling is extremely high but he has found himself below Portuguese duo Joao Neves and Vitinha in the midfield pecking order.
He still made 51 appearances across the course of the 2024/25 season but he was afforded just six minutes in the Champions League final win over Inter Milan.
As such, this summer could be the ideal time to ask about his situation, but while he may not be an automatic starter he still has four years left on his deal and any move won't come cheap.

Reports in France have suggested he will be available for around £85million this summer and while United don't have an endless pot of money to spend, the upside of signing a player of Zaire-Emery's profile may make it a deal worth pursuing.

headline: Man United dream Viktor Gyokeres transfer scenario emerges in £59.7m Ruben Amorim boost
body: Manchester United appear to have received a boost if they look to sign Sporting striker Viktor Gyokeres this summer.

The Swede has been heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford ever since his former head coach, Ruben Amorim, arrived in November. A reunion made sense, with United needing a proven goalscorer and Gyokeres looking for a new challenge in his career.

But the Reds' failure to qualify for next season's Champions League seriously dented those hopes, and it was thought that Premier League rivals Arsenal would now be his preferred destination. The Gunners are also more realistic title challengers next season, and at 27, Gyokeres will be looking to join a team capable of winning major trophies.
Arsenal do not just have Gyokeres on their list of potential attacking targets this summer, though. Benjamin Sesko, previously linked with United himself, is also on Mikel Arteta's shortlist.

And now, German publication Bild has provided some welcome news for United. It is said that RB Leipzig have dropped the asking price of Sesko, which could in turn hand Amorim a welcome boost in his pursuit of Gyokeres.

It was previously thought that the Bundesliga side were demanding a fee of between €80million and €100m (£68m and £85m) for Sesko. That had put off the north London club, who reacted by exploring alternative options.

However, it is now being suggested that a fee of €70m (£59.7m) might be enough for the 22-year-old. Sesko is under contract with Leipzig until June 2029 and scored 21 goals in 45 games across all competitions last season.

The Slovenian is seen as Arsenal's preferred option up front this summer, and with him now potentially being available for a cheaper fee, his move to the Emirates Stadium is much more likely. That will only be good news for United if they look to sign Gyokeres.

It comes after the forward rejected a financially lucrative move to Saudi Arabia in May. Al-Hilal made a £55m offer, which Sporting rejected, but Gyokeres made clear he had no intention of moving to the Gulf state - and he wants to continue to compete in Europe.
As such, the Sweden international is reportedly increasingly aware that his best bet this summer may be to reunite with Amorim in Manchester.

headline: Why £45m transfer snub could be good news for Manchester United
body: Manchester United are slowly but surely starting to change their approach to the transfer market.
The club are desperate to make the 'United tax' a thing of the past, but their problems haven't been limited to buying players for the right price.

Selling players for the right price has also been an issue, but United are looking to adopt a strategy that has brought a number of their rivals success in recent years. Adding sell-on clauses to deals means the financial boost that comes with selling a player can extend beyond the initial payment received.
Teams like Manchester City have made millions from sell-on clauses in recent seasons, and United are looking to follow suit.

It's a ploy that could be set to hand them a timely boost this summer, with former United left-back Alvaro Fernandez rumoured to be on Real Madrid's wishlist. United included a sell-on clause in the deal that saw Fernandez leave Old Trafford for Benfica in 2024, meaning any move he makes this summer will add to the United kitty.

Anthony Elanga is another former United player who could be set to switch clubs this summer. Newcastle United are hoping to lure the Sweden international to St James' Park, and the eye-watering fees being reported mean United could be set for a substantial windfall thanks to their sell-on clause.
Nottingham Forest are said to have rejected a £45million offer, with £60m reportedly set to be enough to prise him away from the City Ground.
If the two teams can thrash out a deal then Forest will seemingly bank in excess of £45m. But not all of that will be added to their bank account.
If a move does materialise, the more Forest can get for Elanga, the better it will be for United.

headline: New Jadon Sancho transfer twist as Man United seek £25m deal in PSR boost
body: An update has been provided on the future of Manchester United forward Jadon Sancho.

The 25-year-old spent last season on loan at Premier League rivals Chelsea, but - despite their £25million obligation to make that move permanent - the Blues opted to pay a £5m penalty fee to send him back to Old Trafford.

United will be hoping to sell the winger this summer as they look to strengthen their attack. It is believed that the former Borussia Dortmund former does not have a long-term future under Reds boss Ruben Amorim and is expected to leave United M16 again. Clubs from Italy, including Juventus and Napoli, have been linked as well as Turkish giants Fenerbahce.
But it is being reported that Fenerbahce are not currently in talks to sign the Englishman. Journalist Fabrizio Romano claims that their main focus is former Aston Villa striker Jhon Duran.
Napoli sporting director Giovanni Manna has also appeared to suggest a switch to the Serie A side will not happen, unless he lowers his existing demands.
"Our offer is clear, we will not pay Sancho's requested salary," he said via journalist Yagiz Sabuncuoglu on X.
The Reds want to secure a similar fee to the one that was agreed with Chelsea, in the region of £25million, despite what was a largely disappointing spell in west London.
Sancho scored five goals and provided 10 assists in 41 matches for the Blues, who ended the season by winning the UEFA Conference League and finishing in the top four.

headline: Manchester United will discover £137m transfer reality next week
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe's suggestion that Manchester United would have gone bust by Christmas had they not implemented a number of cost-cutting measures was extreme to say the least. But it's clear the club isn't in the best place financially.

No European football next season means United need to be more careful than ever before in the transfer market, and so sales will be absolutely necessary if they're to sign the players Ruben Amorim needs to make his 3-4-2-1 system work.

United have already forked out £62.5million for Matheus Cunha, while a bid in excess of £60m has been tabled for Bryan Mbeumo. With a striker, midfielder, goalkeeper and maybe even a full-back still on the club's summer wishlist, players need to go before players can arrive.
It's been no surprise to see business slow down in recent weeks, with the Premier League's financial year ending on June 30.

A lot of clubs will be waiting until after that date passes to complete deals that have been in the works for a number of weeks, and so next week should provide a clearer picture of what is going to be possible for United in this summer's transfer window.

United are looking to offload a whole host of players this summer, with Marcus Rashford, Antony, Jadon Sancho and Alejandro Garnacho on the list of priority sales. The club are prepared to sell any player in transfer window if the right offer is tabled, but the aforementioned quartet simply must be moved on.

United want £40m for Rashford and they must sell Antony for £32.5m to avoid making a loss on the Brazilian under the league's profitability and sustainability rules. £15m would see United avoid making a loss under PSR rules on Sancho, and it's difficult to see them getting any more than that given his form in recent years and the fact that Chelsea paid £5m to avoid committing to a £25m deal for the former Borussia Dortmund man.
Napoli tabled a bid of £40m for Garnacho in January, and United are said to want north of that figure this summer. £50m might be enough to sign the Argentina international.
If United can move all four players on, they'll hope to add roughly £137m to their kitty.
Whether that is possible will become clear next week as the June 30 'deadline' passes and clubs look to kick into gear in the transfer market.
If news of parties interested in Rashford, Antony, Sancho and Garnacho doesn't ramp up next week, United could be in for a long summer.

headline: Viktor Gyokeres team-mate sends message to Man United transfer target as saga continues
body: Viktor Gyokeres is refusing to let this summer's drawn-out transfer saga affect his mood as he shared a light-hearted snap of his Sporting CP team-mates replicating his celebration on Friday night.
The 27-year-old has been front and centre of nearly every gossip column in recent weeks as he continues to be linked with moves to Manchester United and Arsenal.

The Sweden international was one of the most prolific performers in Europe last term as he scored 54 goals in 52 appearances across all competitions for Sporting CP. The forward seems set to leave the Portuguese capital this summer, with the Primeira Liga champions reportedly demanding a fee of close to £85 million for the former Coventry City and Swansea City.

But despite the little progress on the transfer front after the Sporting CP president revealed last week that there had been no offers for Gyokeres, the Swede appears to still be in a jovial mood. On Friday night, Gyokeres shared a post on Instagram that showed Sporting CP defender Zeno Debast performing the forward's now iconic celebration.

Earlier this week, it was claimed that Gyokeres made a plea to the club's president to force through a transfer to Arsenal ahead of Sporting CP's return to training next week. The report from Portuguese outlet Record claims that the 27-year-old's agent has been in touch with the Gunners' sporting director Andrea Berta.

United have also been linked with a move for the forward, who was signed by Ruben Amorim in 2023. But despite the reports in the national press about Gyokeres' eagerness to leave Sporting CP, it appears he still has the backing of his team-mates.
Publicly, Gyokeres has said very little but did take to Instagram earlier this month. "There is a lot of talks at the moment, most of it false," he said.
"I will speak when the time is right."

headline: 'Without a doubt' - Man United given five reasons why they should sign Premier League striker
body: Former midfielder Paul Ince would like to see Manchester United turn to Aston Villa star Ollie Watkins in their search for a striker.

United are desperate to recruit a centre-forward this summer and are currently exploring alternative avenues after missing out on Liam Delap, who joined Chelsea from Ipswich Town earlier this month for £30million.

United continue to be linked with the likes of Sporting Lisbon striker Viktor Gyokeres and Napoli's Victor Osimhen, both of who have established themselves as two of the best strikers in Europe, but they are yet to make an official approach for a centre-forward.
It is no secret United will almost certainly have to rely on sales to fund the addition of a No.9, meaning it remains to be seen who they will be able to turn to.

However, if it is possible, Ince, who was speaking ahead of the Manchester #RifeDontMiss Challenge, which is offering the public the opportunity to win £50,000 and break the world record for the longest putt at American Golf Trafford at the beginning of next month, would like to see United swoop for Watkins, who scored 16 Premier League goals last season.

"He has got all of the attributes that you want to go to Manchester United. I am not saying that is going to be the case, but if you look at last season when [Marcus] Rashford went to Villa Park, Watkins got his nose put of joint and didn't really play much.

"There might be something where if he was available, I'd be looking at him for sure. I think Gyokeres has done well in Portugal, and you have got to remember that he scored a lot of goals at Coventry before he went there."
Watkins, 29, joined Villa from Brentford in 2020, has scored 50 Premier League goals since the start of the 2022/23 season, establishing himself as one of the division's most reliable goalscorers.
United, however, have been unable to rely on a reliable striker in recent seasons. They turned to Rasmus Hojlund in August 2023, signing him from Atalanta, but he has struggled to deliver the goods.
Ince, though, has sympathised with the Dane, highlighting how he arrived at Old Trafford as a 20-year-old and was immediately tasked with spearheading United's attack.
"I honestly think Hojlund is one of those where he is still young and he needs someone who can come in and take the weight off his shoulders," Ince added.

"I think he is better as a second striker who might come on later on in a game. When you are asking a young lad to deal with the pressures of Man United, at Old Trafford, at such a young age and to have to keep scoring goals, it puts a lot of pressure on him.
"I think someone like Watkins would take the pressure off him. Maybe they should send Hojlund out on loan for a year and let him score some goals, come back and be confident."

Paul Ince spoke ahead of the Manchester #RifeDontMiss Challenge, celebrating the launch of the new RIFE Black Edition putters. To register for the final qualifier and be in with a chance of winning £50,000, sign up here.

headline: Brentford make major announcement amid Bryan Mbeumo to Manchester United transfer wait
body: Brentford have announced the appointment of Keith Andrews as their new head coach, as Manchester United continue to pursue a deal for Bryan Mbeumo.

Amid rumours around Mbeumo's future at the Gtech Community Stadium, the Bees have also been searching for a new manager following the departure of Thomas Frank, who replaced Ange Postecoglou at Tottenham Hotspur.
Andrews has now been appointed as Frank's successor, having previously worked as Brentford's set-piece coach.
"Pretty humbled would be the overriding feeling, honoured that I’m the person that’s been chosen to take the club into the next chapter," Andrews said in an interview with Brentford's club website.
"I’m very appreciative of the owner, the board and the staff that have supported this decision. It’s an opportunity I feel I’m very capable of doing and ready to do.

“I don’t know where to start in terms of what’s exciting me because there’s so much: the potential of the football club, the potential of the players and the potential of the staff that underpin what has brought success to this brilliant football club."

One of Andrews' first jobs as Brentford head coach could be finding a solution to Mbeumo's potential move to United. There has been confidence from United that the forward would choose a move to Old Trafford rather than the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium.
Should a deal be completed, Mbeumo would join Matheus Cunha in completing a move to United this summer.

headline: Five Manchester United stars face fight for future ahead of pivotal period
body: Manchester United return to pre-season training next month ahead of the new campaign.

Matheus Cunha will be the headline act as the Reds ramp up preparations for the 2025-26 season. Ruben Amorim's side will hope to improve on their dismal domestic showing last term and travel to America for a summer tour as well as playing in Sweden and at Old Trafford.
United's players will report to Carrington following their summer break in the week commencing July 7. And several stars face make or break periods during the next few weeks.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.
The arrival of Cunha and expected signing of Bryan Mbuemo mean that the attacking ranks will be bolstered while Amorim is keen to add a central striker.

It means Rasmus Hojlund, who struggled in front of goal last season, is under pressure. The Dane faces losing his place in the side next term if a new striker arrives and he has been linked with an Old Trafford exit.
United splashed an initial £72million on the frontman and haven't had a return on their investment.
But pre-season gives him a chance to build some momentum ahead of the new campaign. If his struggles continue, his United future will be in jeopardy.
Hojlund is not the only one with question marks over his long-term position within the squad.

Andre Onana, who is set to remain as first choice goalkeeper despite an error-strewn 2024-25, needs a stable start to ensure his place doesn't come under further threat, while Luke Shaw must prove he is capable of offering form and fitness after suffering with several injuries in recent years.
He could find a home as a left-sided centre-back in United's set-up but it remains to be seen if he will be able to convince Amorim of his durability.

In midfield, Manuel Ugarte and Kobbie Mainoo have yet to fully convince Amorim. The latter has been in and out of the side through injury and form while he has been used in a variety of positions by the Reds chief, seemingly suggesting that the Portuguese boss hasn't quite settled on how best to utilise the England international.
Ugarte had a mixed debut campaign at Old Trafford and despite working under Amorim earlier in his career, United are looking at potentially adding an athletic midfielder over the summer.
That would place extra pressure on Ugarte and the Uruguay international will hope he can convince his manager of his importance over the coming weeks.
Amorim has shown already that he is not afraid to make big calls, United have several big names who still need to convince.

headline: Marcus Rashford Man United transfer latest - Barcelona compromise, Newcastle stance, exit pathway
body: A name who continues to be talked about a lot during the current summer transfer window is Manchester United’s Marcus Rashford.

The forward is expected to leave Old Trafford this summer, having spent the second half of last season on loan with Aston Villa. Unai Emery’s men do have the option to make the move permanent for a £40million fee, but that move now seems unlikely.

The £40million asking price is also open to other clubs as United look to move the player on and raise funds. Any money made on the transfer would go down as pure profit in terms of PSR for the club, given that Rashford is an academy graduate.
Here is the latest on what is being said around his future and a move away from United.
Newcastle United were one of the teams linked with an interest in the United forward this summer, but the Sun reports that the Magpies have no plans to pursue the signing.

The club are instead chasing deals for former United winger Anthony Elanga and Brighton and Hove Albion’s Joao Pedro. Newcastle saw a first bid for Elanga turned down by Nottingham Forest but are reportedly readying a new £50million offer.
Barcelona remain keen on a move for Rashford this summer, even if they do sign Nico Williams, according to the Guardian.
The report says that Barca value Rashford’s ability to operate both out wide and in a more central role. It is, however, said that the Catalan club are looking for a loan deal.

That could potentially see them pay a loan fee to United. However, it is said that the club may be forced to have to contribute to paying a proportion of the forward’s £370,000 per-week salary if a move can be agreed.

A move to Barcelona for Rashford may be cleared with Ansu Fati closing in on a transfer to Monaco. The 22-year-old is expected to join the French side on a loan deal from Barcelona, meaning that Rashford would have less competition for places on the left wing.
Ansu Fati has been spotted arriving at an airport with claim that he is set to travel to France to complete his loan move.

headline: Manchester United supporters deliver transfer window verdict as Bryan Mbeumo deal close
body: Manchester United are closing in on the signing of Brentford attacker Bryan Mbeumo. As reported by the MEN on Thursday afternoon, the Old Trafford club tabled a new and improved bid in excess of £60million for the Cameroon international after an opening offer worth £55m was turned down earlier this month.
Talks between United and Brentford have continued in recent weeks and a deal is now on the brink of being finalised. United have already signed Matheus Cunha from Wolves this summer.
As previously reported by the MEN, United made strengthening their attacking options their leading priority this summer and Reds supporters have been having their say on transfer business.
While Clyde73 believes: "Break another rule and get Harvey Elliott from Liverpool a direct replacement for McTominay, a player who is box to box and scores goals."
But DAVES replied: "Transfers between United & Liverpool are few & far between, so this will never happen. Besides, he's not that good, runs around a lot for no apparent reason!"

Garth123 wrote: "I agree, the funds for the two no 10's have always been there and ring fenced for that purpose. I expect Mbuemo to join shortly after July 1st as that is the start of the new financial year.

"It's no surprise to me that the club are concentrating their efforts in improving the front 3 who were for most parts poor last season. The defence conceded 4 fewer goals than the season before when we came 8th.
"Therefore despite the links, a new GK is not a priority as the short comings have always been the front 3."

Spottheball99 remarked: "Totally agree, De Ligt is a top centre half, I don't understand the criticism he gets. Also Hojlund must work on his first touch, he is nowhere near Prem level at the moment."
What are your thoughts on Manchester United's transfer tactics? Comment below or HERE to join in the conversation.

headline: Emi Martinez to Man United transfer update as £40m deal reality becomes clear
body: An update has been provided on the future of Manchester United-linked Emiliano Martinez.

The 2022 World Cup-winning goalkeeper faces an uncertain future at Aston Villa. Martinez was seen in tears after the Villans' final home game of the Premier League in 2024/25 as he considers starting a new chapter in his career.

Martinez signed a new contract 10 months ago, committing his long-term future to the club. However, it now appears uncertain. After failing to secure a financially lucrative place in next season's Champions League, Villa could be tempted to cash in on the 32-year-old, who turns 33 later this year.

But any hope of Martinez joining the Reds this summer still appears remote at this stage. The Independent's Miguel Delaney has claimed in his latest newsletter that any move for the Argentine is still seen as some way off.
Martinez is also thought to have admirers in Saudi Arabia with a lucrative move to the Gulf state on the cards. A transfer fee of around £30-40million has been suggested.
The shot-stopper himself is said to be "open" to a move to Old Trafford. And now United have seemingly been advised on why they might have the advantage in any transfer battle.

Reports from The Mirror indicate United forward Alejandro Garnacho - subject to paper talk himself this summer - has told friends and family that key figures in the Argentina national team camp have advised him to seek a move to one of the stronger European leagues this summer in the event he departs Old Trafford.

Garnacho, too, has mooted interest from Saudi Arabia but, in outlining the above, sources close to the player are mindful that playing in a less competitive division might hamper his chances of selection for next summer's World Cup finals in Canada, Mexico and the United States.
That would seemingly be the case for Martinez, as well, even though he's well-established between the posts as not only a World Cup winner, but a veteran of 50-plus senior caps.

headline: Man United £125m transfer decision hands Ruben Amorim wildcard that will save millions
body: It's fair to say that Manchester United have successfully built excitement around them this summer with Matheus Cunha already signed and Bryan Mbeumo imminent. But excitement brings expectation.

United went into the transfer window with little expectation. An eighth-placed finish in the Premier League under Erik ten Hag was followed by an 15th-placed finish under Ruben Amorim - the club's worst season in 51 years.

Excitement has also been lacking at Old Trafford. United lost nine home games in the league last term, scoring 23 and conceding 28. Tottenham, Bournemouth, Brighton, Crystal Palace, Wolves and West Ham all enjoyed journeys to the Theatre of Dreams.

However, like it or not, the page has turned and the new season offers a fresh perspective where dreams are created. United have to do better than last campaign but, realistically, a top-five finish has to be the objective.

Cunha's £62.5million signing from Wolves at the start of the summer got the ball rolling. The Brazilian is a ready-made signing with experience in the Premier League, scoring 27 in 65 league games in a struggling Wolves team.

Mbeumo's numbers are even better. The Brentford ace is set to come in after United submitted an offer in excess of £60million this week and will slot perfectly in the vacant role alongside Cunha behind the striker. Mbeumo scored 20 Premier League goals last season; that's more goals than Alejandro Garnacho, Rasmus Hojlund, Joshua Zirkzee and Marcus Rashford combined.

Bruno Fernandes and Amad were United's top-scorers in the Premier League with eight. The pair are two crucial profiles to Amorim's system and are expected to play big parts. However, there's a question lurking over the head of Carrington on Amad.

The 22-year-old enjoyed a breakthrough season for United with 43 matches, 11 goals and 10 assists. Amad missed two months of action at the start of 2025 due to an ankle injury, came back and he was immediately in Amorim's starting XI.

Yet the double signing of Cunha and Mbeumo challenge his place in one of those two positions in United's attack. Fortunately, Amorim is one step ahead and has revealed the Ivory Coast international's secondary position.

Back in November when Amorim took charge of United, Amad started at right wing-back with Noussair Mazraoui starting at right centre-back - his strongest position - and Diogo Dalot on the left. Fernandes and Garnacho played behind Rashford in attack.

In that match, it took Amad less than two minutes to make an impact, too. A neat interchange with Fernandes in United's half, he beat two Ipswich players before delivering an inch-perfect cross for Rashford to open the scoring.

Amad also started at right wing-back in the 4-0 thrashing of Everton a week later. Further appearances at wing-back against Nottingham Forest, Southampton - where he even went on to score a 12-minute hat-trick late on - and Rangers followed before he was used further forward.

Upon his return from injury, the 22-year-old was utilised as a makeshift wing-back in two more games, but he was predominately one of Amorim's two attacking midfielders. In the Europa League heartbreak in Bilbao, he partnered Mason Mount.

Amad isn't going to be shunned out of the United squad. The signings of Mbeumo and Cunha provides healthy competition for the versatile attacker, something certain players have avoided and kept their place in the team.

Reports this week have claimed that United will target four more signings after Mbeumo is finalised - and players are sold. A new striker, a midfielder, a wing-back and a goalkeeper are all positions on their radar.

A quick glance at the wing-backs across world football and you'll have a difficult job at finding an offensive, smart and athletic one who will cost a decent price. Denzel Dumfries and Theo Hernandez have been mentioned in the past, with players like Maximilian Mittelstadt, Miguel Gutierrez, Vanderson, Maxim De Cuyper and Sergino Dest all available, but are they better than what United currently have?

Amad has already proved his reliance and ability to play at right wing-back. His availability to do so allows Dalot to play at left wing-back, thus taking the pressure off having Luke Shaw fit. Don't forget Patrick Dorgu. United are well stocked.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo: Manager ‘says yes’ to Al-Nassr amid Man Utd legend’s decision on next boss
body: According to reports, Manchester United legend Cristiano Ronaldo has decided who he ‘wants’ to manage Al-Nassr and they have ‘said yes’ to the move.
As this story proves, Ronaldo has quite a lot of power at Al-Nassr and this has likely been the case since he joined the Saudi Pro League outfit at the start of 2023.

The five-time Ballon d’Or winner opted to accept a move to the Middle East club after parting ways with Man Utd at the 2022 following a heated dispute with former boss Erik ten Hag and the Glazer family.
Ronaldo has scored goals for fun over the past couple of years, netting 93 goals in 105 appearances, but he missed out on team silverware during the 2024/25 campaign.
Reports in recent months have indicated he is unhappy at Al-Nassr after they finished third in the Saudi Pro League and lost in the AFC Champions League semi-finals.
READ: Ronaldo, Mbappe and Haaland top football’s highest earners as Messi misses out

Ronaldo has been heavily linked with an exit in recent months as he was coming up to the end of his Al-Nassr contract and he was initially expected to leave to play at the Club World Cup, with Al-Hilal, CF Monterrey and Botafogo mooted as possible destinations.
Despite this, Ronaldo eventually decided to commit his future to Al-Nassr, penning a two-year contract extension until 2027.
Before signing a new contract, a report in May claimed Ronaldo had a list of demands during negotiations with Al-Nassr. One such plea was for the club to sack Stefano Pioli and appoint a new manager.
Ronaldo eventually got his wish, with Pioli’s exit from Al-Nassr confirmed earlier this week.
Al-Nassr have since turned their attention to appointing a new manager and they appear to have settled on Jorge Jesus.

MORE CRISTIANO RONALDO COVERAGE ON F365…
👉 So-called ‘world record’ holder Cristiano Ronaldo has actually scored zero proper goals for Portugal
👉 Saudi chief claims Cristiano Ronaldo was blocked from joining ‘biggest’ rival for one key reason
👉 ‘We are not friends’ – Lionel Messi makes honest Cristiano Ronaldo rivalry admission
Jesus recently left rivals Al-Hilal, who have replaced him with Simone Inzaghi, and he’s also had spells at Fenerbahce, Benfica and Sporting Lisbon.
The 70-year-old could be set for a speedy return to management, with journalist Santi Anouna revealing he has held ‘talks’ with Ronaldo over a move to Al-Nassr.
Aouna tweeted: ‘Cristiano Ronaldo and Jorge Jesus have already talked together. CR7 wants Jorge Jesus on the bench of Al-Nassr
‘Jorge Jesus has already said yes to Al-Nassr. Negotiation underway to try to reach an agreement.’
Foot Mercato have provided more details, claiming discussions are ‘progressing well’ for Jesus.
‘Al-Nassr is indeed negotiating with the 70-year-old coach. And the discussions seem to be going in the right direction.
‘Indeed, while a full agreement has not yet been reached, the deal is progressing well and the Portuguese coach wants to join Cristiano Ronaldo ‘s team.’
According to reports, FC Barcelona legend Lionel Messi has been ‘offered a blockbuster’ transfer and he has made a decision on his ‘priority’.
Including Cristiano Ronaldo and Kylian Mbappe (but not Lionel Messi), here are the top 10 highest earners in world football.
Five-time Ballon d’Or winner Cristiano Ronaldo has signed a new contract at Al Nassr and will remain in the Saudi Pro League until he’s 42 years of age.
Lionel Messi spoke openly about his rivalry with Cristiano Ronaldo, revealing they aren’t friends but share great respect.
Liverpool will hope Alexander Isak can become one of the finest signings made by a Premier League champion, but Manchester United will take some budging.
Al-Hilal’s chief executive has explained why the Saudi Pro League side did not sign Al-Nassr star Cristiano Ronaldo ahead of the Club World Cup.

headline: Transfer rumour power ranking: Arsenal bid rejected as Arteta’s Chelsea obsession continues
body: Arsenal will go back with an improved offer for a Spain youngster after adding another Chelsea reject to their shortlist…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) 🆕 Nicolas Jackson – Chelsea to Arsenal
If this happens, Mikel Arteta needs locked up. Surely Jackson is not the answer to Arsenal’s striker crisis?

19) 🔽 Alexander Isak – Newcastle to Liverpool
We’re keeping this in the top 20 for now because, based on absolutely nothing whatsoever, we get the sense that something could happen here. Even if it’s just that Liverpool make a move upon which they are told to f*** all the way off. But selling Isak doesn’t have to be the end of the world for Newcastle.

18) Marcus Rashford – Manchester United to Barcelona
Of course Rashford wants to join Barca, and the forward must have received some encouragement from the Catalans that they will take him. But only on their terms. Which involve a loan, not a purchase. Which United must have seen coming.

MORE ON THE SUMMER 2025 TRANSFER WINDOW
👉 Every Premier League transfer and release confirmed in the summer of 2025
👉 Twenty biggest transfers in the world in 2025 summer transfer window

17) Rodrygo – Real Madrid to Arsenal
Arsenal’s ‘dream signing’, apparently. And it could be a go-er since the Brazilian has had his nose put out of joint by Real, and he’s asked to leave. Real have even lowered their asking price from £85million since it became clear absolutely no one was prepared to pay that much. But Arsenal could find themselves chucking a small fortune at Rodrygo.

16) Marc Guehi – Crystal Palace to Liverpool
With a year left on his contract and a renewal unlikely, Palace are willing to cash in on their captain, who could be the subject of a ‘significant offer’ from the champions when they receive the Jarell Quansah money. The contract situation is important; it means Liverpool will be reluctant to spend over the odds, and while Palace won’t have their pants pulled down, they cannot risk the prospect of their skipper leaving for free.

15) Bryan Mbeumo – Brentford to Tottenham
Spurs are reported to have piqued Mbeumo’s interest and the prospect of staying in London to play for a manager he trusts would certainly appeal. But now United have returned to Brentford with a second offer, how serious are Spurs about reuniting Mbeumo and Thomas Frank?

14) Anthony Elanga – Nottingham Forest to Newcastle
Newcastle failed with an opening £45m offer for Elanga, with Forest apparently looking for £60million. Which seems… excessive? Newcastle have sought to compromise at £50million. Forest are thinking it over…

13) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Spurs and Arsenal are reportedly set to battle it out for the FA Cup-winning England star, who is unlikely to leave Palace for less than his £68m release clause. He’s not exactly an out-and-out left-winger but that’s probably where he’ll play for either team, and that’s a position of priority for the Gunners, while Spurs recently signed Mathys Tel permanently.

12) 🔼 Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting Lisbon to Manchester United
The story goes that Gyokeres has told United he’s up for joining them now Arsenal seem to be veering in Sesko’s direction. If you think you’ve heard that before, it’s because you have. But United could become the Swede’s most viable option for a big move this summer. Once the Red Devils sell the players that almost no one wants to buy. For now, though, we’d still make Arsenal favourites… just.

11) Cristhian Mosquera – Valencia to Arsenal
Arsenal have already had one bid rejected for the Spain Under-21 centre-back but they aren’t done. A second round of talks is scheduled but given the speed at which Arsenal are working this summer, we hold little hope of a swift resolution.

10) Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting Lisbon to Arsenal
Even if Sesko is the man most wanted at Arsenal, the Gunners see an opportunity to get more bang for their buck with Gyokeres. The Swede has made it abundantly clear that he wants to leave Sporting, going as far as telling them he won’t report for pre-season training next week. So time is of the essence for Gyokeres but Arsenal are working to their own timetable even if Mikel Arteta wants a new striker to be boarding the plane for the pre-season tour on July 19.

9) Joao Pedro – Brighton to Newcastle
Chelsea were linked with the Brighton striker but Newcastle always seemed most keen, which has led to a £50million offer. Brighton reportedly wanted £60million initially, but the forward has made it clear he wants to move on. We would expect the Magpies and Seagulls to find common ground soon. Pedro won’t be going to from the south coast to the North-East to play second fiddle. So what could that mean for Alexander Isak?

8) James Trafford – Burnley to Newcastle
This has been going on for over a year but Newcastle seem more intent to land the Clarets keeper than last summer. Trafford wants the move and Newcastle have offered Burnley £25million plus add-ons. They have already secured a keeper of their own but we expect they’ll squeeze Newcastle a bit more here.

7) Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Arsenal
Arsenal are still refusing to pick a lane. The momentum swung with Sesko, then Gyokeres, now it seems the Slovenian is back in the running. Indeed, some reports suggest Sesko is the preferred option among the big-hitters at Arsenal but Leipzig aren’t willing to roll over and have their bellies tickled. Honestly, we don’t know.

6) Bryan Mbeumo – Brentford to Manchester United
Only the fact that United have made a second bid puts them ahead of Tottenham. We’re still waiting to see Spurs’ reaction and whether they counter – Brentford will pray they do something to prolong any bidding war. Apparently, United have been having conversations with the Bees so we have to assume they are confident this offer will suffice, but only if Daniel Levy and Thomas Frank don’t show similar intent.

5) Sverre Nypan – Rosenborg to Manchester City
City have agreed a £12.5million deal for the 18-year-old attacking midfielder and a medical was scheduled for almost a fortnight ago, but we’ve heard nothing since while City are in the United States for a nonsense tournament.

4) Jarell Quansah – Liverpool to Bayer Leverkusen
A £34million deal has been agreed – that’s decent money for a back-up centre-back – but Quansah won’t be heading to Germany until after he’s faced them in the European Under-21 Championship final.

3) Kepa – Chelsea to Arsenal
Nice and easy, this, because of the £5million clause in his Chelsea contract. A reminder: he joined them for £72million and remains the world’s most-expensive goalkeeper. Apparently, Kepa has done his medical and put pen to paper on a deal that should give David Raya the heebie-jeebies.

2) Christian Norgaard – Brentford to Arsenal
We thought Brentford might attempt to squeeze more out of Arsenal after their initial bid but it seems £10million plus add-ons has done the trick. A medical is in the offing.

1) Martin Zubimendi – Real Sociedad to Arsenal
This one got the ‘Here we go’ treatment six weeks ago but, finally, the midfielder is in London to sign for Arsenal for £51million. Actually, he’s been there since Monday so we expected an unveiling by now, but we may have to wait for next week.

headline: Man Utd: ‘Enormous demand’ threatens Mbeumo deal with ‘agreement and medical’ claims shut down
body: According to reports, Brentford have set an ‘enormous demand’ for Bryan Mbeumo as Manchester United target the 20-goal forward.
Man Utd have already spent around £62.5m to sign Matheus Cunha from Wolves, with their current focus on landing Mbeumo.
The Brentford standout stepped up following Ivan Toney’s exit, grabbing 20 Premier League goals and seven assists for the London outfit during the 2024/25 campaign.
Having already lost Thomas Frank to Spurs, Brentford could also bid farewell to Mbeumo, who is about to enter the final year of his contract.

Mbeumo, whose Brentford deal could be extended on the same terms until 2027, has attracted interest from Tottenham Hotspur, but The Athletic’s David Ornstein confirmed on Friday that he has ‘informed’ all parties that he intends to join Man Utd this summer.
‘Mbeumo  wants to join Manchester United, subject to the clubs reaching an agreement, and they contacted Brentford to discuss a switch.

‘An opening offer worth £45million plus £10m in add-ons fell some way short of Brentford’s valuation. A second proposal at £55m and £7.5m of bonuses was also rejected — but talks continue as the 20-time English champions attempt to find a compromise.’
READ: Transfer rumour power ranking: Amorim KOs Man Utd deal, Arsenal bid rejected
Ornstein played down suggestions that the Red Devils have an agreement for Mbeumo after a report on Thursday boldly claimed they have settled on a fee with Brentford.

Now, a report from journalist Duncan Castles for Football Transfers claims Man Utd still have work to do if they are to sign Mbeumo, with Brentford setting an ‘enormous demand’ for their prized asset as the Premier League giants ‘face a huge transfer test’.
“Manchester United’s offer for Mbeumo has not reached the level that Brentford expect,” Castles claimed.
“There’s been a fair bit of reporting on this again over the last week, with people saying an agreement is in place and a medical has been pencilled in.

“The guidance I have is that this is not the case. The current offer from Manchester United, the realistic value – i.e. the guaranteed fee plus the bonuses that could realistically be triggered over his career at the club – is over £60m.
“However, Brentford have had an asking price from the beginning that they want £70m guaranteed for the player. And so far they haven’t shifted from that line.”

Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano provided another update on Mbeumo’s situation on Saturday morning. He said: “The negotiations for Bryan Mbeumo to Manchester United remain underway. Direct contacts ongoing.
“Man Utd and Brentford discuss structure of the deal, add-ons crucial details as #MUFC remain confident.
“Mbeumo informed all parties 3 days ago about clear desire: Man United.”
Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo has reportedly informed his club and Tottenham ‘of his decision to sign’ for Manchester United, following a ‘trust’ suggestion relating to Thomas Frank.
Manchester United and Brentford have agreed a fee for the transfer of Tottenham Hotspur transfer target Bryan Mbeumo, according to reports.
Manchester United have already reportedly made a ‘decision’ on their ‘next three signings’ after Bryan Mbeumo, with a ‘fee agreed’ for the Brentford star.
Tottenham Hotspur have reportedly identified a ‘statement signing’ to pursue during this summer’s transfer window as they close in on another deal.
Man Utd have submitted a second bid for Bryan Mbeumo as the Red Devils also see an Aston Villa star as a ‘serious option’ this summer.
Tottenham seem to be moving into a good position to land a man who Fabrizio Romano has revealed Thomas Frank discussed “as soon as he signed his contract” at the ...

headline: ‘£4bn’ Liverpool repeat ‘doable’ for PSR-ed Newcastle with three factors amid ‘same old Spurs’
body: Three factors are key to PSR-ed Newcastle United producing a repeat of Liverpool’s £4bn growth, while it’s the ‘same old Spurs’ under Thomas Frank…
Send your views to theeditor@football365.com…

What does Liverpool know about PSR…?
To funstar andy:
No, Liverpool wasnt always top 5 or top 8 since the 1950s. Why, there’s a gigantic statue of Bill Shankly becos he won LFC the championship in 1962… the 2nd division championship (back when the top division was division one). We spent at least a couple years looking up from a lower division.
And big 6? Maybe. For some periods of time.

But after we were sold to Dumb and Dumber Hicks and Gillette, who proceeded to shave us bald (ok, cold joke), we almost went bankrupt in 2010. If FSG (then known as NESV) hadnt convinced RBS to sell us for £300mil, we’d have been in administration, booted to Champo division, with no guarantee that we’d be back. We most definitely werent big 6 back then, as recently as 2010, barely 15 years ago.

We had Roy Hodgson for manager (whom Stevie G thot the world of, lol, whilst he was critical of Rafa for playing him in his most devastating position of 10 or RW or LW just not 8 or 6), who bought Mark Konchesky for LB. We were in relegation positions when Roy was finally sacked after half a season. We had Joe Cole, whom Stevie G compared to Messi in training, and whom we spent years part paying his salary to get him off our books. We had Milan Jovanovic as our big ticket free agent, porn star lookalike Andriy Voronin as 10, no kidding. And we cheered for david ngog who was an improvement. Torres couldnt wait to jump off the boat the moment he got healthy and better.
2010. FSG brought us back. However tightwad fans think they are, i’d always be grateful to them. They literally brought us back from our darkest time in recent memory.

I know u guys had mike ashley for 14 years from 2007 till 2021. That’s a terrible decade and half, bouncing between divisions. But trust me, u dont want to get anywhere near bankruptcy, the way we did. It was a time lfc could really have disappeared for good.
So no, we werent always top 6 since the 1950s. We almost disappeared in 2010, not too long ago.

As tightwad as fsg are, and as frustrated as i am with them sometimes, they’ve proven their financially prudent management works. The club is profitable and the asset value has risen from £300 mil in 2010 to £3-4bil today. All without investing the kinds of crazy sums that sugar daddies do. (Read: forest, everton). In net spend terms, we’ve been consistently 5th or below, outspent by other clubs below us. So it’s doable, with lots of luck, skill, hard work.

Good luck making your way up!
Gab YNWA
PS Barca still trying their best to turn Luis Diaz head on the cheap, as is Real with Konate. Encouraging them to run down their contracts. Odious clubs. A pox on them both.
READ: Liverpool ‘proud’? They are royalty while Newcastle and Villa get PSR-ed
I read Liverpool supporters’ mails in response to James, NUFC’s entry regarding PSR and Newcastle with interest.
I thought Ldjub – LFC stranded in Salford’s mail thoughtful and interesting; his “do it the right way” point was fairly persuasive.

And Danny, LFC NY (now London) made fair points about the desire of many (most, I’d say) Newcastle supporters to ignore or even venerate the club’s new Saudi owners. And I agree with him that there’s too much whining about PSR from our lot.
Although neither is completely wrong, I think both of them are oversimplifying these matters.

While it’s true that the ostensible reason for PSR was to prevent clubs from unsustainable and destructive spending, that hasn’t particularly worked. Everton is only one EPL club that’s been in financial hot water (and I’m not just talking points deductions) since the rules were introduced. Heck, Ruben Amorim was insisting that ManU was about to go bankrupt at the start of their current spending spree.

Additionally, because I gather that the rules only apply in the EPL, they do nothing to protect the clubs below them, where we’ve seen a number of clubs in dire straits recently. Those are the clubs that need PSR.
Anyway, given that PIF is the richest club owner in the world, what exactly are these rules protecting us from?
I’ve always suspected that PSR rules were also intended to rein in the growth of player costs; if so, it has failed utterly, to the sorrow of us relative minnows.

Whatever the “reasons” for PSR, their effect has been confusion and frustration for clubs and their supporters, as the rules have militated against long- term planning, particularly for clubs bouncing in and out of the UCL. Nobody, but nobody, wanted to sell Elliott Anderson; PSR made that happen. On the other hand, that ridiculous deal last summer might have been (for us) the result of counting unhatched chickens with the Tonali and Gordon buys, given the 2023-24 league table.

And every Liverpool supporter should understand that they were already among the richest clubs in the world in 2013, no matter how long it had been since they’d won the league: 10th in the world, according to a 2014 Forbes article using 2013 data. This was also the year that Real Madrid replaced ManU as the world’s wealthiest club.

Whether Liverpool’s earlier long domination of English football was a result of doing things “the right way” is an open question, as far as I’m concerned. How often were they able to throw their financial weight around with smaller clubs? A lot, I’m guessing.

But still, I’m hugely ambivalent about PSR. It frustrates me on behalf of clubs like Newcastle and Forest. But by not allowing a club like Newcastle to buy a billion dollars worth of players this summer, they do prevent all clubs (except evidently Chelsea) from just buying success. That’s a good thing. And yet again, they have contributed to a concentration of wealth at the top. That’s bad.
I think there are versions of PSR that really would work and be fair, but this version ain’t one.

(Also, Danny was just wrong about our recent signings. This is our fourth consecutive window without a first- team signing. It’s not complete, and we’ll sign players, but I should think James, NUFC could be forgiven for calling 22 months two years.)
Chris C, Toon Army DC
